div.p: I came out here on the Memphis and Charleston R.R. yesterday and without any trouble got board with a widow lady named Houston who is a native of Petersburg, Virginia, and who has yet a few of the houseservants in the yard who have not left here the meals I have eaten here are the best cooked I have eaten since I left home it puts me in mind of old times. There are five regements stationed at this place under the command of Brig Gen Tuttle so that there is no danger to be apprehended as there is a party of soldiers stationed every few miles along the R.R. to preserve it from destruction there are numbers of Guerillas in the neighborhood but they do no damage except by taking provisions. The country has not been cultivated the past seasonand the people are suffering for food-my duty will be to grant them permits to purchase from the stores in their place. small quantities of clothing groceries provisions. the such as will lent them two months and only on application of the head of the family

so you see I will soon become acquainted with every person in the 7 counties comprising my district the country is very broken and the residences are splendid and the grounds are very beautiful. I am told but most of the enclosures are brokendown and the plants destroyed the yard where I am and the next one are in pretty goodcondition with a wide walk about 100 yards from the gate to the house with a row of red cedar about 15 feet high on either side and the walks are edged with sweet violet the whole distance so that bushels may be gatheredat once coming out of Memphis there are a number of fine houses and grounds which have not been disturbed and looked beautiful as we passed through in the cars. The people who remain that is the union ones are extremely bitter in their denunciations of the Confederates. Much more so than any one with you. there are however many who have to take the oath who are still thought to be secessionists and probably are. I have had no trouble in traveling and have never taken the oaths of allegiance nor been asked for it. I have a free pass on the R.R. to and from Memphis. but as I hope to be busy will not go down often there are some perquisites of office besides $4 per day which will probably pay my expenses.

I hope so so that I may send you all the money I can I hope you received my letter of the 22_ from Memphis I would have written you again but was busy all day in the offices and you know I can not write well at night in fact the room in which I write this is rather dark and the weather so cold that I have to sit by the fire (a wood fire in an old fashioned fire place) but I can scarcely see the lines and the ink is rather pale last night was really cold the water froze in the basin after the fire I left when I went to bed (a good hard feather bed almost as hard as a new hair mattress) and the breath misted the bed clothes the room is a good sized room out in the yard by itself and a Wm Stark from Philadelphia rooms with me there being two double beds in the room and plenty of room besides. He is a pious man and after we got to bed said I was the first man he had seen bow his knee to his maker in private for 12 months he also did the same. He has been in business here for many years and knows the people well. I have an office in the same building with the Private Marshal Lt Col Reclns of Des Moins who looks very like John Smith, the same black hair and eyes and dark complexion he told me yesterday evening that Gen

Tuttle paid me a high compliment said he liked my looks and thought we could get along together so you see that looks will for my comfort for here the Military are the Masters. I have not heard a word from home since I left but hope to hear tomm when you write direct to Mr Wm R. Hackley Local Agent - Tres. Dept. La Grange, Tenn. as the men in the P.O. will be more particular than they would otherwise be in sending them on-I want to see you all very very much - Kiss my boy for me - I will by and write again some time this week. God preserve you all
WR Hackley Mrs Wm. R Hackley Iolut

Nov 31st I was much disappointed in not getting a letter from home this morning but suppose it was delayed in Memphis. The weather is very cold here and I think of you when morning comes and there is no fire I hope you will keep a fire all night and hope by Jany you may be able to keep three as I think that their place is better than I thought it would be. you had better get some large envelopes and direct to me as Local Special Agent Treasury Dept as then the letters will be more promptly forwarded by the different Post offices through which they will pass - Love to all Take Care of yourselves
